{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3732738,"name":"James ","username":"TullE564","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tulle564/{size}/226301_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-06T21:40:43.243Z","cooked":"

Hello CD!

I want to preface this by saying that I am a mechanical guy for our team, and know little about sensors or programming. I am currently working on a CAD model of a robot that will shoot tennis balls, and I wanted to add a sensor to know when my magazine of balls was full. I’ll show what I have below, but it is a rotating section of channels similar to that seen on some clay pigeon throwers. I am planning on having a ground intake feed these channels and I need this sensor to sense when one is full so it could tell the code to rotate to the next channel. This sensor would be mounted stationary ~6in from where the balls would be. I was initially thinking about using a REV color or distance sensor to find this out, but didn’t know the pitfalls or pros of either. Which would you use, or would you recommend something different? Thanks!

IMG_27071062×729 78.7 KB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-09-06T21:40:43.243Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":103,"reads":195,"readers_count":194,"score":569.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":506053,"topic_slug":"sensor-question","display_username":"James ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60429,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Driver"},"post_url":"/t/sensor-question/506053/1","custom_user_title":"Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3732747,"name":"Yuval Gur | Electronics & Software mentor","username":"YuvalGur-2231","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/df788c/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-06T21:54:43.645Z","cooked":"

Where are you planning to mount the sensor?

Anyway I would recommend not using REV sensors unless you truly have no other choice. The are known to cause program loop overrun (when connected via I2C on the roborio). In general - simpler and cheaper analog IR distance sensor, or simple Adafruit beam breaks, do the job just as well and are much cheaper.

I was planning on adding a structure as tall as those columns a few inches away to mount the sensor to. I also didn’t know that about REV Sensors thank you!

So yes, I’d use one of the two simple sensors I’ve mentioned.

Another option is a Banner reflective proximity sensor. We use it extencively in our robot, but it can get quite expensive. Consider using an AliExpress version, from my experience it works almost as well as the original…

I’ve had good experience with the Aliexpress version of this Amazon listing. (Amazon can get it to you quickly, which might be relevant.)

They work well (have adjustable distance sensing) if you can get them to be looking “through” a blank spot on the bot that is sometimes occupied by a game piece. Worst case, buy 5-10 of them to have on hand from somewhere.

We feed the digital output straight into a Rio DIO port.

My team uses Pololu sensors extensively. I see they cost a lot more than they used to so we may have to reuse them from old robots. Pick the range and connector variant.

The known issue with I2C bus on the roboRIO was mentioned and it applies to all devices not just Rev’s. A workaround using an intermediary device is posted in the WPILib known issues documentation. My team’s experience is we had more problems with the MXP I2C bus than the onboard so we don’t use either.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-09-07T12:58:12.440Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":28.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":506053,"topic_slug":"sensor-question","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.pololu.com/product/4066","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pololu Digital Distance Sensor 25cm","clicks":19},{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/yearly-overview/known-issues.html#onboard-i2c-causing-system-lockups","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Known Issues — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sensor-question/506053/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3733194,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-07T18:41:41.187Z","cooked":"

Banner sensors are in our experience very reliable, if also somewhat expensive and not as easy to source as some others.

Last year we started using LaserCAN with good results and I expect we will continue to do so. They are CAN based, so easy to integrate. They have the additional advantage of being able to be tuned to a narrow detection area (both width and depth) unlike some sensors which are more diffuse; for example we had one on last year’s robot looking for a piece of coral between the end effector rollers. Their Achilles’ heel used to be the difficulty in setting them up (software and procedure were problematic) but @Sam_Dare assures me that Thrifty Config’s new support for LaserCAN will make that a thing of the past. We haven’t tried it out yet so I can’t comment on direct experience.
